page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 161: Line 161:
==August==
==August==
â
On first August, the first day of [[Ramadan]], Egyptian soldiers clashed with protesters in Tahrir Square, tearing down tents the activists have used for the sit-in that where hundreds of protesters have been sleeping in the square since July 8.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassieb |first=Ingy |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-military-police-break-up-tahrir-square-sit-in/2011/08/01/gIQAnvPOnI_story.html |title=Egyptâs military police forcibly break up Tahrir Square sit-in |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> Egyptian forces swinging electrified batons and shouting the battle cry âGod is greatââ yesterday swiftly chased off dozens of activists who had refused to end four weeks of renewed protests at [[Tahrir Square]] to pressure the countryâs transitional military rulers. Hundreds of riot police backed by armored vehicles and soldiers moved in to tear down the camp of dozens of tents after a group of holdout activists - some of them relatives of people killed in the uprising that toppled [[Hosni Mubarak]] in February - refused pleas over loudspeakers to go home. Some in the crowd hurled stones at the police.<ref>{{cite web|title=Soldiers clear Tahrir Square to end latest protests|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-08-02/news/29843122_1_ammar-ali-hassan-tahrir-square-hosni-mubarak|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=4 August 2011}}</ref> Protesters' rights groups said that the military police detained 66 people in the process.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marches planned to free Egypt protesters|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/08/02/Marches-planned-to-free-Egypt-protesters/UPI-56181312292823/|publisher=http://www.upi.com/|accessdate=4 August 2011}}</ref> The removal of the Tahrir sit-in was a calculated political move. Average citizens had been growing weary of the lack of mobility in the central square, so when the military showed up on early Monday afternoon they were met with cheers. Most Egyptians support the militaryâs actions.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egyptâs liberals push limits as Mubarak trial gets under way|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/08/03/egypt%E2%80%99s-liberals-push-limits-as-mubarak-trial-gets-under-way.html|accessdate=4 August 2011|newspaper=http://www.dawn.com/}}</ref>
+
On first August, the first day of [[Ramadan]], Egyptian soldiers clashed with protesters in Tahrir Square, tearing down tents the activists have used for the sit-in that where hundreds of protesters have been sleeping in the square since July 8.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassieb |first=Ingy |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-military-police-break-up-tahrir-square-sit-in/2011/08/01/gIQAnvPOnI_story.html |title=Egyptâs military police forcibly break up Tahrir Square sit-in |publisher=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> Egyptian forces swinging electrified batons and shouting the battle cry "'''God is great'''" yesterday swiftly chased off dozens of activists who had refused to end four weeks of renewed protests at [[Tahrir Square]] to pressure the countryâs transitional military rulers. Hundreds of riot police backed by armored vehicles and soldiers moved in to tear down the camp of dozens of tents after a group of holdout activists - some of them relatives of people killed in the uprising that toppled [[Hosni Mubarak]] in February - refused pleas over loudspeakers to go home. Some in the crowd hurled stones at the police.<ref>http://articles.boston.com/2011-08-02/news/29843122_1_ammar-ali-hassan-tahrir-square-hosni-mubarak</ref> Protesters' rights groups said that the military police detained 66 people in the process.<ref>http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/08/02/Marches-planned-to-free-Egypt-protesters/UPI-56181312292823/</ref> The removal of the Tahrir sit-in was a calculated political move. Average citizens had been growing weary of the lack of mobility in the central square, so when the military showed up on early Monday afternoon they were met with cheers. Most Egyptians support the militaryâs actions.<ref>http://www.dawn.com/2011/08/03/egypt%E2%80%99s-liberals-push-limits-as-mubarak-trial-gets-under-way.html</ref>
â  
The trial of Hosni Mubarak and his two sons Ala'a and Gamal, along with former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]] and six former top police officials began on 3 August 2011 at a temporary criminal court at the Police Academy in north Cairo. The charges are corruption and the premediated killing of peaceful protestors during the mass movement to oust him, the latter of which carries the death penalty.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/201161131532286483.html Mubarak and sons to stand trial in August] Al Jazeera. Retrieved 1 June 2011</ref> The trial was broadcast on Egyptian television, with Mubarak making a surprise first appearance since his resignation, brought in on a hospital bed and held in a cage for the session. Upon reading out the charges to him, Mubarak pleaded not guilty, denying responsibility for the charges against him. Judge Ahmed Refaat adjourned the court, ruling that Mubarak be transferred under continued arrest to the military hospital on the outskirts of Cairo, with the second session scheduled for 15 August.<ref>{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Judge Says TV Will Show Mubarak on Trial|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/01/world/middleeast/01egypt.html|accessdate=31 July 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=31 July 2011|author2=Fahim, Kareem}}</ref>
The trial of Hosni Mubarak and his two sons Ala'a and Gamal, along with former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]] and six former top police officials began on 3 August 2011 at a temporary criminal court at the Police Academy in north Cairo. The charges are corruption and the premediated killing of peaceful protestors during the mass movement to oust him, the latter of which carries the death penalty.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/201161131532286483.html Mubarak and sons to stand trial in August] Al Jazeera. Retrieved 1 June 2011</ref> The trial was broadcast on Egyptian television, with Mubarak making a surprise first appearance since his resignation, brought in on a hospital bed and held in a cage for the session. Upon reading out the charges to him, Mubarak pleaded not guilty, denying responsibility for the charges against him. Judge Ahmed Refaat adjourned the court, ruling that Mubarak be transferred under continued arrest to the military hospital on the outskirts of Cairo, with the second session scheduled for 15 August.<ref>{{cite news|last=Afify|first=Heba|title=Judge Says TV Will Show Mubarak on Trial|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/01/world/middleeast/01egypt.html|accessdate=31 July 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=31 July 2011|author2=Fahim, Kareem}}</ref>
